Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.

are suffixes. Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. A suffix can change the words meaning and how it is used in a sentence.
(est). Use Phonics/Syllable Cards for support. Point out that the
ending is used to compare two things. For example:
Jans room is cleaner than Gregs room.
ending is used to compare three or more things. For example:
The kitchen is the cleanest room in our house.
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.

Read, Build, Write: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., After school, I usually _____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.

Use Phonics/Syllable cards to review affixes. Remind students that a prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word and a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. Review that adding a prefix or suffix to a base word changes the words meaning and its part of speech. Write the words
. Guide students to identify the base word and tell how the affixes change the words meaning.

. Have students identify whether each word contains a prefix or a suffix. Record each group of words in a separate column. Invite volunteers to underline the affix in each word, noting whether it appears at the beginning or the end of the word.
Have students select two of the words from the list and write sentences for them.
This word means the opposite of empty.
Add a suffix to full to make a word that describes a bag with the most items in it.
Replace the base word in fullest to make a word that describes a tree that is the least tall.
Replace the suffix in shortest to make a word that means the opposite of taller.
Replace the base word in shorter to make a word that means the opposite of dirtier.
Replace the base word in cleaner to make a word that means the opposite of lighter.
Read, Build, Write: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
